<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;
    int32                           return_code;
    int                             how;

    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /* Note that when called via the shared layer,
     * the "Mode" arg has already been checked/validated. */
    if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
    {
        how = SHUT_RD;
    }
    else if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
    {
        how = SHUT_WR;
    }
    else
    {
        how = SHUT_RDWR;
    }

    if (shutdown(conn_impl->fd, how) == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:

{

int32 OS_SocketShutdown(osal_id_t sock_id, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Confirm that "Mode" is one of the 3 acceptable values */
    BUGCHECK(Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ || Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE ||
                 Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE,
             OS_ERR_INVALID_ARGUMENT);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if (stream->socket_type == OS_SocketType_STREAM && (stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED) == 0)
        {
            /* Stream socket must not be connected */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(&token, Mode);

            if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                if (Mode & OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
                {
                    stream->stream_state &= ~OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE;
                }
                if (Mode & OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
                {
                    stream->stream_state &= ~OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;
                }
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
</additional code>

explanation:
I selected the above fragments because Rule 17.2 (no direct or indirect self-calls) requires inspecting call sites and the functions they invoke to determine whether any call chain leads back to the same function. The OS_SocketShutdown function calls OS_SocketShutdown_Impl, and both functions reference/invoke other routines/macros (OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdRelease, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET). Any of those could (directly or indirectly) call back into OS_SocketShutdown or OS_SocketShutdown_Impl, producing indirect recursion; therefore these call sites and their targets should be investigated.

Fragments not listed do not need investigation for Rule 17.2 because they contain only local data handling, simple conditionals, or state updates that do not perform function calls that could form a recursion cycle (for example, the Mode validation logic, the stream state bit manipulations, and the inline OS_ObjectIndexFromToken definition are local and do not call other functions). The POSIX shutdown() call in the Impl function is a well-known library call and is not expected to call back into the OS layer; however, its invocation site is included above only for completeness of the Impl function context. To fully rule out indirect recursion, inspect the implementations of OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdRelease, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro/inline), and any functions they call to ensure none call back into OS_SocketShutdown or OS_SocketShutdown_Impl.
